answers.answer: I can relate.  I heard the warnings also when young like you.  I ignored them, including not taking the Statin drugs.When I was wheeled into the catherization lab a few years later, I suddenly took all the advice quite seriously.  What you have to know is that once the barn door has been left open to CAD, the damage is done, and all you can do is maintain the status quo.  Since then, I've had at least a dozen heart caths, 10 stents in my heart arteries, a pacemaker and open-heart bypass surgery.  I lost about 40 pounds, brought down my cholesterol numbers and have been able to get rid of diabetes injections.  Hopefully, you can visualize your future and make changes and not have to endure reality therapy.I'd make an appointment with a dietician as soon as possible, begin exercising at least 20 minutes a day, walking qualifies.  Keep us informed.

question: Ever since my doctor told me I am at high risk for hard attack, diabetes, etc. I am trying to motivate myself to do something about it.  I am failing and I do feel scared thinking that I could be taken away from my kids lives too soon. I am 38 years old female. I am 5'3" and 180 pounds.My cholesterol level is 225Triglycerides 560HDL 26LDL 161My CHOL/HDL RATIO is 8.65  (1.00 - 4.44 Normal range)My dad died when he was 53 from diabetes complications. His mom (my grandmother) died when she was 52 from diabetes.My doctor put me on Fenofibrate 160 mg and Lipitor 40 mg.Is that going to help?I know my choice of food is my main issue, but I have very hard time to stop. If these numbers above are not enough for me to realize this is a serious situation, I don't know what is going to take for me to wake up.If anyone was in similar situation what did motivate you? I need help :(Thank you for reading.
title: Why I have a hard time to take this seriously?
